text:
Prince Harry accepted Attitude magazine's Legacy Award on behalf of his mother, Princess Diana, tonight. The publication, known as UK's leading gay magazine (Prince William became the first royal to grace its cover last year), recognized the late Princess for her charity work with people suffering from AIDS.

In his speech—nearly two months after the 20th anniversary of his mother's death—Harry remembered the famous moment when Diana shook hands with an AIDS patient in the late '80s, thus challenging stigmas against those suffering with the illness.

"In April 1987, my mother was only 25 years old," he began. "She was still finding her way in public life, but already she felt a responsibility to shine her spotlight on the people and issues that were often ignored. She knew that AIDS was one of the things that many people wanted to ignore and seemed like a hopeless challenge."

Princess Diana meeting with AIDS patients in Brazil in 1991. Getty Images

"She knew that the misunderstanding of this relatively new disease was creating a dangerous situation when mixed with homophobia," the Prince explained.

"So in that April, she shook the hand of a 32-year-old man with HIV in front of the cameras," he later said. "She knew exactly what she was doing—she was using her position as Princess of Wales, the most famous woman in the world, to challenge everyone to educate themselves, to find their compassion, and to reach out to those who need help instead of pushing them away."

Harry added, "She wanted the world to know the stories of those who were dying."



Prince Harry accepting the Legacy Award at this year’s #AttitudeAwards on behalf of his mother Princess Diana’s HIV/AIDS activism 🌈 pic.twitter.com/ViVxCWdqnR — Attitude (@AttitudeMag) October 12, 2017

Like his mother, Harry has put great effort into charity work with victims and patients of HIV/AIDS. In 2006, he established Sentebale, an organization that supports children affected by HIV in Lesotho and Botswana, Africa. He also memorably got tested for HIV with Rihanna in Barbados to raise awareness on World AIDS Day in 2016.

Decades after her passing, Diana's legacy of empathy and philanthropy live on through her children.
